abstract: China First Heavy Industries set its $1.67 billion Shanghai initial public offering price below the top of its range, the first to do so since China resumed I.P.O.s last June, and a sign of growing realism as markets weaken and regulators demand more rational pricing.
snippet: China First Heavy Industries set its $1.67 billion Shanghai initial public offering price below the top of its range, the first to do so since China resumed I.P.O.s last June, and a sign of growing realism as markets weaken and regulators demand m...
lead_paragraph: China First Heavy Industries set the share price for its $1.67 billion initial public offering in Shanghai below the top of its range, the first to do so since China resumed I.P.O.s last June, and a sign of growing realism as markets have weakened and regulators have demanded more rational pricing, Reuters reported.

headline.main: China Heavy I.P.O. Reflects Slipping Demand
